S1.T1.caption: Table 1: Goal of this study
S1.T1.table:
Purpose Analyze
Object set of classes
With the purpose of Evaluation
With respect to the efficiency of federated learning approach to detect God class code smell in different scenarios
Viewpoint from researchers and practitioners point of view
In the context of closed-source software companies
references: The Goal-Question-Metric (GQM) approach is commonly used in by Software Engineering community for formulating studies’ goals
Per and Martin (
); Wohlin et al. (
. We used the GQM to determine the objective of this study as follows:
Based on the defined goal, we formulated the following research questions and hypotheses.
How can federated learning be effectively leveraged for God Class code smell detection?
How does the use of federated learning affect the quality of the resulting ML model compared to the individual models generated by centralized training approaches?
For this purpose, the null hypotheses have been formulated as follows:
Federated learning cannot be effectively leveraged for God Class code smell detection.
Federated Learning does not improve the quality of the resulting ML model compared to the individual models generated by centralized training approaches.
The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section

introduces background on code smell detection, federated learning, and data privacy and attacks.
Section

describes the proposed approach.
Next, Section

analyses and discusses the results.
Section
presents related works. while Section
discusses the critical evaluation of the study. Finally, Section
presents conclusions and recommendations for future work.

S4.T2.table:
Dataset

references:
To examine the proposed approach, we used three datasets from the literature: Alkharabsheh et al. (2019); Arcelli Fontana et al. (2016); Pecorelli et al. (2020), which are shown in Table 2. The 1st and 2nd datasets were constructed by Arcelli Fontana et al. (2016) and Pecorelli et al. (2020), respectively, whereas the 3rd was collected by our team. The set of software systems used in each dataset were open-source, written in Java, came from different domains and size categories, and were available in different repositories, such as Github and SourceForge. Moreover, they are well-known and widely used in the code smell detection context. Concerning (our) dataset (i.e., the 3rd one), we followed concrete criteria to collect the software systems from the repositories, including the number of downloads, availability in several versions, and the history of software systems’ maintenance. Due to the huge number of systems that met the criteria, we randomly selected twenty four systems. The datasets focused on detecting different types of code smells and the God Class was one of them. Table 2 presents the characteristics of the chosen datasets in terms of the number of projects, the number of classes, the number of detection tools, the number of detected God Classes using tools (GC-Tool), the number of human experts who participated in the manual validation process, and the number of God Classes detected by experts (GC-Experts). The total number of software systems was 111 and was formed of more than 80,0008000080,000 classes. Each dataset was analyzed automatically by a set of detection tools, and the detection results were manually validated by a group of human experts who have good knowledge of code smell detection. The results of the manual validation were formulated as a binary decision (God Class = 1, Not God Class = 0). As a result, the number of false positives God Classes was reduced in all datasets from 2,69626962,696 to 721721721, which represents a 26%percent2626\% reduction. To meet the objective of the study, we pre-processed all datasets to have both same features and format.
Table 3 reports the 16 features of the dataset, their definitions, and the quality dimensions of different software levels. The replication package in k. Alkharabsheh et al. (2021) includes all the datasets.

To examine the proposed approach, we used three datasets from the literature: Alkharabsheh et al. (2019); Arcelli Fontana et al. (2016); Pecorelli et al. (2020), which are shown in Table 2. The 1st and 2nd datasets were constructed by Arcelli Fontana et al. (2016) and Pecorelli et al. (2020), respectively, whereas the 3rd was collected by our team. The set of software systems used in each dataset were open-source, written in Java, came from different domains and size categories, and were available in different repositories, such as Github and SourceForge. Moreover, they are well-known and widely used in the code smell detection context. Concerning (our) dataset (i.e., the 3rd one), we followed concrete criteria to collect the software systems from the repositories, including the number of downloads, availability in several versions, and the history of software systems’ maintenance. Due to the huge number of systems that met the criteria, we randomly selected twenty four systems. The datasets focused on detecting different types of code smells and the God Class was one of them. Table 2 presents the characteristics of the chosen datasets in terms of the number of projects, the number of classes, the number of detection tools, the number of detected God Classes using tools (GC-Tool), the number of human experts who participated in the manual validation process, and the number of God Classes detected by experts (GC-Experts). The total number of software systems was 111 and was formed of more than 80,0008000080,000 classes. Each dataset was analyzed automatically by a set of detection tools, and the detection results were manually validated by a group of human experts who have good knowledge of code smell detection. The results of the manual validation were formulated as a binary decision (God Class = 1, Not God Class = 0). As a result, the number of false positives God Classes was reduced in all datasets from 2,69626962,696 to 721721721, which represents a 26%percent2626\% reduction. To meet the objective of the study, we pre-processed all datasets to have both same features and format.
Table 3 reports the 16 features of the dataset, their definitions, and the quality dimensions of different software levels. The replication package in k. Alkharabsheh et al. (2021) includes all the datasets.

Where Posubscript𝑃𝑜P_{o} represents the samples ratio agreement, and Pesubscript𝑃𝑒P_{e} shows the
expected agreement percentage between samples. Moreover, the interpretation of the kappa values is shown in Table 4.

Evaluating our FedCSD approach in terms of the agreement ratio between the global model prediction and the corresponding actual value demonstrates the robustness of our approach. Figure 6 depicts the Cohen Kappa measured while testing the global model for 100 training rounds. There is a significant improvement in the Kappa value per training round, where the initial agreement was low (around 55%) then linearly converged in the right direction. Further, the Kappa value started to stabilize after round 60 and obtained 79%, which falls in the substantial range as indicated in Table 4. Therefore, the acquired agreement ratio shows the strong learning ability of the FedCSD, which can be generalized for code smell detection problems.

Fawcett (

. It focuses on identifying the relationships between the specificity and the sensitivity of learning algorithms. The ROC values range from 0 to 1. The higher ROC value indicates a better learning model. Table
presents the interpretation of the test.

S4.T6.caption: Table 6: The accuracy achieved by the centralized ML model per dataset
S4.T6.table:
Dataset Model Accuracy
First dataset (Pecorelli et al.) 98.90%percent98.9098.90\%
Second Dataset (Fontana et al.) 92.30%percent92.3092.30\%
Third dataset (Khalid et al.) 99.15%percent99.1599.15\%
references: In this experiment, a centralized ML model was trained over each mentioned dataset to evaluate the performance of the code smell detection model in a traditional company scenario. Table 6 reports the model’s accuracy per dataset. We noticed that the model has achieved a high accuracy over all datasets. For instance, training the ML model over both Khalid et al. and Pecorelli et al. datasets has obtained higher performance with a slight difference related to the number of smells covered by each dataset. Meanwhile, with the Fontana et al.dataset, the model obtained the lowest accuracy (92.30%), where it detected fewer smells that what actually exists. Therefore, we hypothesized that any change in the company’s coding culture or new workers joining the company with different coding behavior will affect the ML model’s performance and cause technical debt.

Comparing our FedCSD accuracy with experiments 1 and 2, we argue that our model outperforms both the centralized and cross-evaluation experiments, despite the FedCSD accuracy being a bit lower than the results obtained from the model trained over Khalid et al. dataset (see Table 6) by almost 0.1%. This difference can be ignored in favor of both the model global knowledge and the model stability provided by the FedCSD.

references: In this experiment, we simulated new changes in the coding behavior that would be caused by a new worker who recently joined the team or by updates in the company policies that have significant impacts on both their internal culture and their products. Therefore, we evaluated the ML model that was trained using one dataset over the other two datasets (cross-evaluation). Table 7 reports the accuracy obtained by the model trained in one dataset and validated over the other two datasets. We noticed that when the model used either Pecorelli et al. or Khalid et al. one for training and one for testing, the model obtained the highest accuracy because both datasets shared the same behavior and distribution.
